Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Gregory Philip Reeves of New Mexico State University to conduct a research project, entitled "Locating a New Disease Resistance Gene in Chile Peppers," during the summer of 2012 at Seoul National University (SNU) in Seoul, South Korea. The host scientist is Dr. Doil Choi.

The intellectual merit is found in the identification of disease resistance genes in chile peppers, which is required for breeding elite disease resistant chile pepper varieties in the future and increasing crop yield by reducing the losses due to plant pathogens. Also, discovery of new disease resistance genes yields new insights into plant/pathogen interactions. Discoveries made in chile peppers can be applied to other crops - for the development of disease resistance in them as well, with significant economic impact on East Asian and U.S. agriculture.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report—“Finding a New Disease Resistance Gene in Chile Peppers”

Background information

Phytophthora capsici is arguably the most destructive pathogen to chile peppers (Capsicum annuum) resulting in annual losses over $100 million (USD) worldwide. A new disease resistance inhibitor gene, found in the chile pepper variety, New Mexico Capsicum Accession 10399 (NMCA10399), represses disease resistance in the chile pepper plant to Phytophthora capsici, but not to other species of Phytophthora. The inhibitor gene makes the plant susceptible, even if it has disease resistance genes. So studying this inhibitor gene at the molecular level will to a better understanding of disease resistance in plants and will make breeding for disease resistance to P. capsici in elite chile pepper varieties easier.

Objectives

  1. Find the area in the chile pepper genome that has the inhibitor gene so that it can be isolated and studied further.
  2. Build a collaboration between my advisor, Prof. Paul W. Bosland of my home institution, New Mexico State University, and my host, Prof. Doil Choi of Seoul National University, which will lead to future projects, shared grants, and more student exchange opportunities.

Results

Several hundred areas were searched on chile pepper chromosomes 1, 2, 3, 5 and 10 (of 12 chromosomes) in a population of chile pepper plants for mapping the inhibitor gene. Half the of chile pepper plants had the inhibitor gene (inhibitor lines), and the other half did not have the inhibitor gene (non-inhibitor lines), but otherwise the plants were closely related. Thus, any genetic differences discovered by this study may be due to the extra inhibitor gene. Due to time constraints, only chromosomes 1, 2, 3, 5, and 10 were searched.

The majority of the areas showed no differences among the inhibitor lines and the non-inhibitor lines. Forty seven areas markers showed differences between the non-inhibitor lines and the inhibitor lines. Of these only one area on chromosome 5 was found which showed a loose association with the inhibitor gene. This may mean that the gene lies on chromosome 5. Further work is needed to validate that this area of chromosome 5 is indeed inherited (linked) to the inhibitor gene and if so, how closely.

In addition to searching for the inhibitor gene by looking at individual areas, the whole genome of NMCA10399 was sequenced. Currently the lab of my host professor, Dr. Doil Choi, is sequencing the chile pepper genome for the first time. The variety being sequenced is the highly disease resistant chile pepper variety, CM-334. Presently, the entire genome of CM-334 has been completed (3.5 Gbp, 88X coverage) and is 85% assembled. Gene prediction (annotation is underway. Also, the NMCA10399 genome was sequenced fully (3.5 Gbp, 10X coverage). It is being assembled using CM-334 as a template genome. Once both are completed, both genomes will then be compared to each other to search for novel gene sequences between them which can be used to locate the inhibitor gene faster and also look for disease resistance genes.

This opportunity to travel and conduct research in South Korea has opened a new door bridging two independent research programs. Future projects between both research institutions have already been discussed. It is expected that the newly sequenced chile genome will provide a wealth of information which can be used for continued collaboration. Overall, I have learned so much through this fellowship opportunity including many valuable techniques that will greatly benefit future research projects. This opportunity will help me become a more successful scientist in future endeavors.
